phases.title: Planning & Preparation
phases.description: Get organized before you start building

steps.title: Verify All Components
steps.description: Check that you have all required parts before starting
steps.content:
Lay out all your components and compare them against your build plan. This prevents mid-build delays and helps you understand what you're working with.

**What to verify:**
1. **Switches** - Count them. You need enough for both keyboard halves plus a few spares
2. **Microcontrollers** - Verify you have 2 (one for each half)
3. **Diodes** - Should match switch count (1N4148 through-hole or SMD)
4. **PCB or wiring materials** - PCB boards or 30AWG wire for handwiring
5. **Connectors** - TRRS jacks and cable for wired, or batteries for wireless
6. **Case components** - Plates, bottom plates, screws, standoffs
7. **Optional features** - RGB LEDs, OLED displays, rotary encoders if chosen
8. **Keycaps** - Verify correct profile and count

**Take photos** of your organized workspace - it helps when you need to remember where things are.
warnings: Missing components will delay your build by days or weeks
Verify microcontroller pin compatibility with your firmware choice before soldering
tips: Create a physical checklist and mark off items as you verify them
Test microcontrollers before soldering - flash a blink sketch to verify they work
Order 10-20% extra switches and diodes in case of failures

steps.title: Set Up Your Workspace
steps.description: Prepare a safe, organized workspace for building
steps.content:
A proper workspace makes building safer and more enjoyable. You'll be here for several hours, so get comfortable.

**Essential setup:**
1. **Work surface** - Clean, flat, well-lit table or desk. Use a cutting mat or silicone mat to protect the surface
2. **Lighting** - Bright overhead light plus a desk lamp for detail work. LED work lights are ideal
3. **Ventilation** - Soldering produces fumes. Work near a window or use a small fan to direct fumes away
4. **Organization** - Small containers or compartmented trays for sorting screws, diodes, resistors
5. **Reference materials** - Keep this guide, your build plan, and component datasheets accessible on a tablet or second monitor

**Comfort:**
- Adjustable chair at proper height
- Take breaks every 45-60 minutes
- Keep water nearby
- Have snacks ready for longer sessions
warnings: Never solder in an enclosed space without ventilation
Keep flammable materials away from soldering iron
Have a fire extinguisher nearby (kitchen ABC type is fine)
tips: Use anti-static mats or wrist straps when handling electronics
Label containers with painter's tape for easy identification
Take photos at each major step - helps with troubleshooting later

steps.title: Prepare Your Tools
steps.description: Gather and prepare all tools you'll need
steps.content:
Having all tools ready prevents workflow interruptions. Here's what you'll need based on your build method.

**Universal tools (all builds):**
- Soldering iron (60W temperature-controlled recommended, 300-350°C for electronics)
- Solder (60/40 or 63/37 rosin core, 0.8mm diameter)
- Flush cutters for trimming component leads
- Tweezers (fine-tipped for SMD work)
- Multimeter for continuity testing
- USB cable (USB-C or Micro-USB depending on controller)

**Handwired builds add:**
- Wire strippers (for 30AWG wire)
- 30AWG solid core wire (multiple colors for rows/columns)
- Helping hands or PCB holder
- Diagonal cutters

**PCB builds add:**
- Solder wick or desoldering pump (for mistakes)
- Flux pen
- Isopropyl alcohol (90%+) and brush for cleaning

**Testing tools:**
- Keyboard testing website (bookmark: keyboardchecker.com)
- Firmware flashing software ready to install

**Prepare your soldering iron:**
1. Clean the tip with brass wire or damp sponge
2. Tin the tip with fresh solder
3. Set temperature to 300-350°C (575-660°F)
4. Let it fully heat before starting work
warnings: Hot soldering irons can cause serious burns - always use a proper stand
Lead solder contains lead - wash hands after soldering, never eat while soldering
Keep soldering iron tip tinned to prevent oxidation
tips: Buy a temperature-controlled iron if you plan to build more keyboards - it's worth it
Keep a damp sponge or brass wire tip cleaner handy and clean often
If you've never soldered, practice on scrap wire first

externalLinks.title: How to Solder - Complete Beginner's Guide
externalLinks.description: 15-minute tutorial covering soldering basics, tools, and techniques

steps.title: Review Your Build Strategy
steps.description: Understand the assembly sequence before starting
steps.content:
Take 15 minutes to read through all the steps ahead. This helps you understand the workflow and spot potential issues before they become problems.

**Understanding your build path:**
Your build method determines your assembly approach. Review the steps specific to your choice:

- **Handwired:** You'll wire the switch matrix manually, giving maximum flexibility but requiring careful planning
- **Custom PCB:** You designed the PCB, so you'll solder components to it following your schematic
- **PCB Kit:** The PCB is pre-designed, making assembly straightforward - just follow the kit instructions

**Build order overview:**
1. Build the key matrix (switches + diodes)
2. Connect the microcontroller
3. Add optional features (RGB, OLED, encoders)
4. Flash firmware
5. Test every key
6. Final assembly into case

**Common first-time mistakes to avoid:**
- Soldering controller before testing matrix
- Wrong diode orientation (very common!)
- Forgetting to test before case assembly
- Flashing wrong firmware for controller type

**Time management:**
Plan for these approximate times:
- Matrix assembly: 3-8 hours (depends on method)
- Wiring controller: 1-2 hours
- Firmware setup: 1-3 hours (first time)
- Testing and troubleshooting: 1-2 hours
- Case assembly: 30-60 minutes

Don't rush. Taking your time prevents expensive mistakes.
tips: Read all warnings in red before starting each phase
Bookmark this page or save the PDF for offline reference
Join the keyboard building Discord communities - they're helpful for real-time questions

phases.title: Build Key Matrix
phases.description: Wire or solder your switches into a matrix

steps.title: Prepare Switches for Handwiring
steps.description: Mount switches in plates and prepare for wiring
steps.content:
Handwiring gives you complete freedom in layout but requires careful planning. Let's get your switches ready.

**Switch mounting:**
1. **Test fit** - Insert a few switches into your plate or case to verify they snap in securely
2. **Plan your layout** - Use keyboard-layout-editor.com to finalize your key positions
3. **Mount all switches** - Press switches firmly into plate until they click. They should be flush and not wobble
4. **Verify alignment** - Look at your keyboard from the side. All switches should be at the same height

**Matrix planning:**
You need to understand how keyboard matrices work:
- Switches are arranged in ROWS and COLUMNS
- Each switch connects one row to one column
- Diodes prevent ghosting and allow n-key rollover
- Typical split keyboard: 3-4 rows, 6-7 columns per half

**Prepare your diodes:**
1. **Check orientation** - Diodes have a cathode (marked with black line) and anode (unmarked end)
2. **Bend leads** - Bend diode legs 90° about 3mm from the body for easier soldering
3. **Sort and organize** - Keep diodes in a container where they won't get mixed up

**Wire preparation:**
- Cut wire into appropriate lengths (add 20% extra for routing flexibility)
- Strip 2-3mm of insulation from wire ends
- Pre-tin stripped ends with a small amount of solder
- Use different colors for rows vs columns (e.g., red for rows, black for columns)
warnings: CRITICAL: Plan your matrix before soldering. Fixing mistakes after is very difficult
Verify switch plate compatibility - some switches only work with specific plate thicknesses
Don't bend switch pins before insertion - this makes removal nearly impossible
tips: Take photos of your switch layout before wiring - you'll reference this constantly
Label rows and columns with painter's tape during assembly
Start with the most accessible row to build confidence

externalLinks.title: Handwiring a Custom Keyboard
externalLinks.description: Detailed photo guide to handwiring process

steps.title: Wire Row Connections
steps.description: Connect switches horizontally using wire
steps.content:
Rows connect all switches in a horizontal line. We'll wire these first, then add columns.

**Wiring strategy:**
Row wiring connects one pin of each switch in a horizontal line. This pin will later connect to a controller GPIO pin.

**Step-by-step process:**
1. **Identify row pins** - Usually the bottom-left or top-left pin of each switch
2. **Route first wire** - String wire from the first switch to the last switch in the row, keeping it taut but not tight
3. **Solder each connection** - Touch iron and solder to the switch pin and wire simultaneously. Hold for 2-3 seconds until solder flows
4. **Inspect joints** - Good solder joints are shiny, smooth, and cone-shaped. Dull or blobby joints indicate cold solder
5. **Trim excess wire** - Cut close to the last switch
6. **Repeat for all rows** - Work methodically row by row

**Quality checkpoints:**
- Each solder joint should be mechanically strong (tug gently to test)
- Wire routing should be clean and organized
- No solder bridges between adjacent pins
- No exposed wire that could short to other connections

**Troubleshooting common issues:**
- **Cold solder joint (dull gray):** Reheat and add a tiny bit more solder
- **Too much solder (blob):** Use solder wick to remove excess
- **Solder won't stick:** Clean the tip, add flux, try again
warnings: Double-check which pin you're using for rows - mixing pins will break your matrix
Keep wires away from plate edges where they might get pinched during case assembly
Let each joint cool completely before moving to the next
tips: Work in good lighting - bad solder joints are easier to spot immediately
Clean your iron tip every 5-10 joints
Use flux if solder isn't flowing smoothly
Take breaks - fatigue leads to mistakes

steps.title: Install Diodes on Row Wires
steps.description: Solder diodes to enable n-key rollover
steps.content:
Diodes are essential for proper keyboard function. They prevent ghosting and allow you to press multiple keys simultaneously.

**Understanding diode orientation:**
This is the #1 mistake in handwired builds. Diodes MUST be oriented correctly:
- **Cathode (black line)** connects to the row wire you just soldered
- **Anode (plain end)** connects to the switch column pin
- ALL diodes in your entire keyboard should point the same direction

**Installation process:**
1. **Verify orientation** - Look at the first diode. Black line should point toward the row wire
2. **Attach cathode to row** - Wrap or solder the cathode (black line end) to the row wire
3. **Position anode** - The anode (other end) should point toward the switch's column pin
4. **Solder both ends** - Ensure good mechanical and electrical connection
5. **Verify with multimeter** - In diode mode, meter should beep in only one direction
6. **Repeat for every switch**

**Working efficiently:**
- Do all diodes in one row before moving to the next
- Keep your orientation consistent (e.g., all cathodes pointing right)
- Test every 5th diode with multimeter to catch orientation errors early

**Visual check:**
When done, all diodes should:
- Point the same direction
- Have shiny solder joints
- Not touch any other wires or components
- Be mechanically secure
warnings: CRITICAL: Wrong diode orientation is hard to troubleshoot later. Test frequently!
Verify orientation on EVERY diode - even experienced builders make mistakes
Don't assume all diodes from one batch are marked the same way
tips: Use a multimeter in diode mode to verify orientation before soldering
Mark the cathode side with a Sharpie on your workbench as a reference
Take a photo of the first row - use it as reference for consistency
Pre-bend all diodes before starting for faster assembly

externalLinks.title: How Diodes Work in Keyboards
externalLinks.description: Visual explanation of diode function and orientation

steps.title: Wire Column Connections
steps.description: Complete the matrix by wiring columns
steps.content:
Column wiring completes your keyboard matrix. Each column connects vertically through the diodes.

**Column wiring connects through diodes:**
Unlike rows (which connected directly to switches), columns connect to the diode anodes. This completes the matrix circuit.

**Installation process:**
1. **Identify column path** - Follow the vertical line of diode anodes
2. **Route wire** - Run wire vertically from top to bottom of the column
3. **Solder to each diode anode** - Connect wire to the diode's plain end (not the black line end)
4. **Keep wire taut** - Prevents tangling and shorts
5. **Verify no shorts** - Use multimeter to check no columns are shorted together
6. **Repeat for all columns**

**Matrix testing:**
Before connecting to the controller, test your matrix:
1. **Continuity test rows** - Each row should have continuity across all switches
2. **Continuity test columns** - Each column should show continuity through diodes (one direction only)
3. **No shorts between rows** - Adjacent rows should NOT have continuity
4. **No shorts between columns** - Adjacent columns should NOT have continuity

**Common issues:**
- **Short circuits:** Usually caused by loose wire strands or solder bridges
- **Open circuits:** Cold solder joints or broken wires
- **Inconsistent results:** Intermittent connections from mechanical stress

**Documentation:**
Create a matrix map showing:
- Which row wire goes to which controller pin (document for later)
- Which column wire goes to which controller pin
- Take a photo of your finished matrix
warnings: Test the matrix BEFORE connecting to controller - shorts can damage the controller
Don't skip continuity testing - finding problems now saves hours later
Label each row and column wire - you'll need this for firmware configuration
tips: Use different colored wire for each column to simplify troubleshooting
Create a wiring diagram as you go - your future self will thank you
Test each column immediately after wiring it
Strain relief: add a drop of hot glue where wires might flex

externalLinks.title: Matrix Testing Guide
externalLinks.description: QMK documentation on handwiring and testing

steps.title: Inspect PCB Kit Components
steps.description: Verify PCB quality and identify components
steps.content:
PCB kits simplify assembly, but you should still inspect everything before soldering.

**PCB inspection:**
1. **Visual check** - Look for cracks, scratches, or manufacturing defects
2. **Check traces** - Ensure no broken traces or lifted pads
3. **Verify holes** - All through-holes should be clean and open
4. **Test continuity** - Use multimeter to verify key traces if you have the schematic

**Component identification:**
Your kit should include:
- 2x PCBs (left and right halves)
- Diodes (usually SMD or through-hole, pre-counted)
- Resistors (if needed for certain features)
- TRRS jacks or wireless components
- Reset button
- Controller sockets or controller itself

**Organize before starting:**
1. **Separate by type** - Diodes in one container, resistors in another
2. **Verify quantities** - Count components against kit manifest
3. **Read kit instructions** - Many kits have specific assembly orders
4. **Identify orientation markers** - Note any polarity markings on PCB

**Assembly order (typical):**
Most PCB kits follow this sequence:
1. SMD components (if any) - resistors, capacitors
2. Diodes (observe polarity!)
3. Controller socket or controller
4. Reset button and TRRS jack
5. Switches or hot-swap sockets
6. Testing
7. Optional features
warnings: Don't assume the kit is complete - verify everything before starting
Some PCBs have top and bottom sides marked - verify before soldering
Follow the kit's specific instructions if they differ from this guide
tips: Take photos of the PCB before starting in case you need to reference later
Use a magnifying glass or phone camera to inspect SMD pads
Test the PCB with a multimeter if you're unsure about its condition

steps.title: Solder Diodes to PCB
steps.description: Install diodes following PCB markings
steps.content:
Diodes on PCBs are easier than handwiring, but orientation is still critical.

**Diode types:**
Your PCB will have either:
- **Through-hole (THT):** Legs go through holes, easy for beginners
- **Surface mount (SMD):** Tiny components soldered to pads, requires steady hands

**Through-hole diode installation:**
1. **Find orientation marker** - PCB will have a line or symbol matching the diode's cathode (black line)
2. **Bend leads** - 90° bend matching hole spacing
3. **Insert diode** - Cathode line matches PCB marking (usually a white line or square pad)
4. **Flip PCB** - Diodes on top, you solder from bottom
5. **Solder joints** - Heat pad and lead together, apply solder, remove iron
6. **Trim leads** - Cut close to PCB with flush cutters
7. **Verify orientation** - Double-check every diode before moving on

**SMD diode installation:**
1. **Apply solder to one pad** - Just a tiny amount
2. **Position diode** - Cathode marker (line) matches PCB marking
3. **Tack one end** - Reheat solder blob, slide diode into place with tweezers
4. **Solder other end** - Apply iron and solder to opposite pad
5. **Reflow first joint** - Apply more solder to first side
6. **Inspect** - Diode should be flat, both sides soldered

**Testing diodes:**
Use multimeter in diode mode:
- Should conduct in one direction (shows ~0.5-0.7V)
- Should NOT conduct in reverse (shows OL or infinity)
- If conducts both ways: solder bridge
- If conducts neither way: bad solder joint or dead diode
warnings: CRITICAL: Diode orientation must match PCB markings. Wrong orientation = keyboard won't work
SMD diodes are tiny and easy to lose - work over a container
Don't overheat SMD components - max 2-3 seconds per joint
tips: Do all diodes in one row, then test that row before moving on
For SMD: use flux pen for easier soldering
Take a break every 20-30 minutes to prevent eye strain
Use magnification (jeweler's loupe or phone camera) for SMD work

externalLinks.title: SMD Soldering Tutorial
externalLinks.description: Techniques for soldering small surface mount components

steps.title: Install Switches or Hot-Swap Sockets
steps.description: Mount switches to complete the matrix
steps.content:
The final step in building your key matrix is installing switches.

**Two approaches:**

**A) Hot-swap sockets (no soldering per switch):**
1. **Identify socket pads** - Two pads per switch position
2. **Apply solder to pads** - Tin each pad with a small amount of solder
3. **Position socket** - Metal contacts should align with pads
4. **Solder contacts** - Heat pad and socket contact simultaneously, let solder flow
5. **Verify alignment** - Socket should be flat and straight
6. **Test with switch** - Insert switch to verify it clicks in securely
7. **Repeat for all positions**
8. **Insert all switches** - After all sockets installed, press switches in

**B) Direct solder switches:**
1. **Test fit switches** - Verify they fit PCB holes without force
2. **Insert switches** - Start with corner switches to align PCB and plate
3. **Check alignment** - All switches should be perpendicular to PCB
4. **Solder two pins** - One on opposite corners to hold alignment
5. **Check again** - Make sure switches are flush and straight
6. **Solder remaining pins** - Work systematically
7. **Inspect all joints** - Shiny, smooth, cone-shaped

**Quality checkpoints:**
- Switches are all at same height
- No wobble when pressed
- Pins fully soldered (or hot-swap sockets fully seated)
- No solder bridges between adjacent pads

**Final matrix test:**
Before connecting controller:
1. Use multimeter to verify each switch connects its row and column when pressed
2. Check for shorts between adjacent switches
3. Document any issues for troubleshooting
warnings: Switches must be fully seated before soldering - check from the side
Hot-swap sockets require less solder than you think - don't overdo it
If plate and PCB don't align, do NOT force switches - check for interference
tips: Install corner switches first to align plate and PCB
For hot-swap sockets: test with one switch before doing all positions
Clean PCB with isopropyl alcohol after soldering to remove flux residue
Label the PCB halves (LEFT/RIGHT) before testing

steps.title: Set Up QMK Build Environment
steps.description: Install QMK toolchain on your computer
steps.content:
QMK is the most popular keyboard firmware. It's powerful but requires some setup.

**Installation process:**

**Windows:**
1. Install QMK Toolbox (graphical flasher): Download from GitHub releases
2. Install QMK MSYS: `winget install qmk/qmk/qmk_toolbox` or download installer
3. Open QMK MSYS terminal
4. Run: `qmk setup` - This downloads QMK firmware and sets up build environment
5. Follow prompts (default options are usually correct)

**macOS:**
1. Install Homebrew if not already installed: `/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"`
2. Install QMK: `brew install qmk/qmk/qmk`
3. Run setup: `qmk setup`
4. Install drivers if prompted

**Linux:**
1. Install via package manager: `python3 -m pip install --user qmk`
2. Run setup: `qmk setup`
3. Install udev rules for device access: `sudo cp util/udev/50-qmk.rules /etc/udev/rules.d/`

**Verify installation:**
```
qmk doctor
```
This checks that all dependencies are installed correctly.

**Test compilation:**
```
qmk compile -kb handwired/dactyl_manuform/4x5 -km default
```
If this compiles without errors, your environment is ready!
warnings: QMK setup downloads several GB of data - ensure you have good internet and disk space
Don't skip 'qmk doctor' - it catches problems before you waste time
Windows Defender may flag QMK tools - this is a false positive, you can allow it
tips: Save the QMK folder location - you'll need to navigate here often
Create a bookmark folder with QMK docs and your keyboard's documentation
Join QMK Discord for real-time help: https://discord.gg/qmk

steps.title: Configure QMK Keymap
steps.description: Create or customize your keyboard layout
steps.content:
Now you'll create your keymap - the layout that defines what each key does.

**Option 1: Use QMK Configurator (easiest):**
1. Visit https://config.qmk.fm/
2. Select your keyboard from dropdown (or choose similar model)
3. Click keys to assign functions
4. Add layers for special functions (Fn layer, numpad, etc.)
5. Click "Compile" - wait for firmware to build
6. Download .hex or .bin file

**Option 2: Edit keymap locally (more control):**
1. Navigate to keyboards folder: `cd ~/qmk_firmware/keyboards/`
2. Find or create your keyboard folder
3. Copy default keymap: `cp -r keymaps/default keymaps/my_layout`
4. Edit `keymaps/my_layout/keymap.c` in your text editor
5. Compile: `qmk compile -kb your_keyboard -km my_layout`

**Keymap basics:**
- **Layers:** Multiple layouts accessed via layer keys (like Fn key)
- **Keycodes:** KC_A = key A, KC_ESC = Escape, etc.
- **Modifiers:** KC_LSFT = Left Shift, LCTL_T(KC_A) = Ctrl when held, A when tapped
- **Special functions:** RGB controls, media keys, mouse keys

**Common beginner mistakes:**
- Forgetting to set split keyboard options in config.h
- Wrong matrix dimensions
- Incorrect pin assignments
- Missing bootloader definition

**Split keyboard specific settings:**
In your `config.h`:
```c
#define MASTER_LEFT  // or MASTER_RIGHT
#define USE_SERIAL   // or USE_I2C
#define SOFT_SERIAL_PIN D2  // your TRRS connection pin
```
warnings: Save your keymap file(s) somewhere safe - rebuilding from scratch is frustrating
Test basic layout first before adding complex features
Don't enable too many features at once - controllers have memory limits
tips: Start with a default keymap and modify gradually
Use QMK Configurator for first builds - it prevents syntax errors
Keep a layer for troubleshooting with clearly labeled test keys
Document your keymap - you'll forget what layers do!

steps.title: Flash QMK Firmware to Controllers
steps.description: Upload your firmware to the keyboard
steps.content:
Time to flash your firmware and bring your keyboard to life!

**Preparation:**
1. **Identify bootloader:** Your controller type determines flash method:
   - Pro Micro / Elite-C: Caterina bootloader (uses avrdude)
   - RP2040 boards: Drag-and-drop UF2 files
   - STM32: DFU mode (uses dfu-util)
2. **Compile firmware:** `qmk compile -kb your_keyboard -km your_keymap`
3. **Locate firmware file:** Usually in `qmk_firmware/.build/` folder
   - AVR (Pro Micro): `.hex` file
   - RP2040: `.uf2` file
   - STM32: `.bin` file

**Flashing process:**

**Option A: Using QMK Toolbox (recommended for beginners):**
1. Open QMK Toolbox
2. Select your .hex/.bin/.uf2 file
3. Select MCU type from dropdown
4. Connect keyboard via USB
5. Put controller in bootloader mode:
   - Press reset button, OR
   - Bridge RST and GND pins with tweezers, OR
   - Double-tap reset (if configured)
6. QMK Toolbox should detect device (yellow text)
7. Click "Flash"
8. Wait for success message
9. Repeat for second half of split keyboard

**Option B: Using command line:**
```
qmk flash -kb your_keyboard -km your_keymap
```
Then put controller in bootloader mode when prompted.

**Verification:**
1. Keyboard should be detected by computer
2. Check Device Manager (Windows) or System Information (Mac)
3. Try pressing a few keys
4. If no response: reflash or check wiring

**Troubleshooting flash issues:**
- **Not detected:** Wrong bootloader selected, or drivers not installed
- **Flash fails midway:** Bad USB cable, try different port
- **Keyboard works but keys wrong:** Matrix pins incorrect in firmware
- **Only one half works:** Check TRRS connection and master/slave configuration
warnings: NEVER disconnect during flashing - can brick the controller
Flash one half at a time - don't connect both halves during flashing
Verify you're flashing correct firmware for your controller type
tips: Keep a spare firmware file that you know works - makes recovery easier
Label controllers LEFT and RIGHT immediately after flashing
Test thoroughly before case assembly - flashing later is harder
Save your compiled .hex/.uf2 file - you can reflash without recompiling

steps.title: Flash and Configure Vial
steps.description: Install Vial firmware for GUI configuration
steps.content:
Vial is a fork of QMK with a graphical configurator. No recompiling needed to change your keymap!

**Why Vial?**
- Change keymap without reflashing
- Real-time configuration via GUI app
- Built on QMK foundation
- Perfect for beginners or those who change layouts frequently

**Installation steps:**

1. **Download Vial configurator:**
   - Visit https://get.vial.today/
   - Download for your OS (Windows/Mac/Linux)
   - Install the application

2. **Get Vial firmware:**
   - Check if your keyboard has official Vial support: https://get.vial.today/keyboards/
   - If supported: Download .hex/.uf2 file directly
   - If not supported: You'll need to compile Vial firmware using QMK

3. **Flash Vial firmware:**
   - Use QMK Toolbox or command line to flash
   - Same process as flashing QMK (see previous step)
   - Put controller in bootloader mode
   - Flash the Vial .hex/.uf2 file
   - Repeat for both halves

4. **Configure in Vial app:**
   - Connect keyboard via USB
   - Open Vial configurator
   - Keyboard should be auto-detected
   - Click keys to reassign
   - Changes apply immediately - no reboot needed!

**Vial features:**
- **Layers:** Add up to 8 layers
- **Macros:** Record and assign macros
- **Tap Dance:** Multi-function keys
- **Combos:** Key combinations
- **Key Overrides:** Context-sensitive keys

**Split keyboard setup:**
Make sure to set:
- Master/slave configuration (usually auto-detected)
- TRRS communication settings
- Test both halves independently
warnings: Not all keyboards have Vial support - check compatibility first
Vial firmware is slightly larger than basic QMK - may not fit on older controllers
Save your Vial configuration file - makes recovery easier
tips: Test Vial configurator BEFORE final assembly - ensures firmware works correctly
Export your layout from Vial regularly (File → Save Layout)
Use Vial's test matrix feature to verify all keys work
Enable Secure mode in Vial for additional security

steps.title: Set Up ZMK for Wireless Keyboards
steps.description: Configure ZMK firmware for Bluetooth keyboards
steps.content:
ZMK is designed specifically for wireless keyboards with Bluetooth. Perfect for nice!nano builds.

**Why ZMK for wireless?**
- Designed for low power consumption
- Native Bluetooth support
- No USB cable needed between halves
- Active development and community

**ZMK uses GitHub Actions for building:**
You don't need to install anything locally! Firmware builds in the cloud.

**Setup process:**

1. **Fork ZMK config repository:**
   - Visit https://github.com/zmkfirmware/unified-zmk-config-template
   - Click "Use this template" → "Create new repository"
   - Name it: `zmk-config` (or whatever you prefer)
   - Set to Public (required for GitHub Actions free tier)

2. **Configure your keyboard:**
   - Edit `config/boards/shields/your_keyboard/your_keyboard.conf`
   - Set keyboard name, manufacturer
   - Configure split settings:
     ```
     CONFIG_ZMK_SPLIT=y
     CONFIG_ZMK_SPLIT_BLE=y
     CONFIG_ZMK_SLEEP=y
     ```

3. **Configure keymap:**
   - Edit `config/your_keyboard.keymap`
   - Uses devicetree syntax (different from QMK)
   - Define layers, keys, behaviors
   - Example:
     ```
     bindings = <
       &kp ESC  &kp Q  &kp W  &kp E  &kp R
       &kp TAB  &kp A  &kp S  &kp D  &kp F
     >;
     ```

4. **Commit and push:**
   - Commit your changes to GitHub
   - GitHub Actions automatically builds firmware
   - Wait 5-10 minutes for build to complete
   - Download .uf2 files from Actions tab

5. **Flash to controllers:**
   - nice!nano uses UF2 bootloader (drag-and-drop)
   - Double-press reset button on nice!nano
   - It appears as USB drive
   - Drag .uf2 file to drive
   - Controller auto-reboots
   - Repeat for both halves (left and right have different files)

**Pairing keyboards:**
1. Turn on both halves
2. They auto-pair with each other
3. On computer: Open Bluetooth settings
4. Look for keyboard name
5. Click to pair
6. Start typing!
warnings: ZMK requires specific wireless controllers (nice!nano, nrfmicro, etc.)
GitHub Actions free tier has limits - don't spam builds
Save your working .uf2 files - rebuilding takes 5-10 minutes
tips: Use the ZMK config template - it has everything pre-configured
Test with simple keymap first before adding complex features
ZMK has excellent documentation - read it before asking for help
Join ZMK Discord for community support

steps.title: Install KMK (CircuitPython Firmware)
steps.description: Set up KMK for RP2040-based keyboards
steps.content:
KMK is written in Python and runs on CircuitPython. Perfect for RP2040 controllers and beginners!

**Why KMK?**
- No compilation needed - edit Python files directly on the controller
- Easy to understand - it's Python!
- Rapid iteration - save file, keyboard reboots automatically
- Great for learning how keyboards work

**Requirements:**
- RP2040-based controller (Raspberry Pi Pico, KB2040, etc.)
- CircuitPython installed
- USB connection (KMK doesn't support wireless yet)

**Installation process:**

1. **Install CircuitPython on controller:**
   - Download CircuitPython .uf2 for your board: https://circuitpython.org/downloads
   - Put controller in bootloader mode (double-press reset)
   - Controller appears as USB drive named "RPI-RP2" or similar
   - Drag .uf2 file to drive
   - Controller reboots as "CIRCUITPY" drive

2. **Install KMK firmware:**
   - Download KMK: https://github.com/KMKfw/kmk_firmware/archive/refs/heads/master.zip
   - Extract zip file
   - Copy the `kmk/` folder to root of CIRCUITPY drive
   - Copy the `boot.py` file to root of CIRCUITPY drive

3. **Create your keymap:**
   - Create file: `CIRCUITPY/code.py`
   - This is your main keyboard configuration
   - Example minimal split keyboard:
     ```python
     import board
     from kmk.kmk_keyboard import KMKKeyboard
     from kmk.keys import KC
     from kmk.modules.split import Split
     
     keyboard = KMKKeyboard()
     
     # Split configuration
     split = Split(
         split_flip=True,
         split_side=None,  # Auto-detect
         use_pio=True,
     )
     keyboard.modules.append(split)
     
     # Matrix configuration
     keyboard.col_pins = (board.GP0, board.GP1, board.GP2)
     keyboard.row_pins = (board.GP4, board.GP5, board.GP6)
     keyboard.diode_orientation = DiodeOrientation.COL2ROW
     
     # Keymap
     keyboard.keymap = [
         [  # Layer 0
             KC.Q, KC.W, KC.E, KC.R, KC.T,
             KC.A, KC.S, KC.D, KC.F, KC.G,
         ]
     ]
     
     if __name__ == '__main__':
         keyboard.go()
     ```

4. **Save and test:**
   - Save code.py
   - Controller auto-reboots
   - Test keys!
   - Edit code.py to refine keymap
   - Save again, auto-reboot, test again

**Debugging:**
- Serial console shows errors: Use Mu Editor or any serial terminal
- Connect at 115200 baud
- Python errors print to console
- Much easier to debug than compiled firmware!
warnings: KMK only works on CircuitPython-compatible controllers (mainly RP2040)
No wireless support yet in KMK
Slightly higher latency than compiled firmware (usually not noticeable)
Edit code.py carefully - syntax errors prevent keyboard from working
tips: Use a good text editor with Python syntax highlighting
Test with minimal keymap first before adding features
Read KMK docs - lots of examples and modules available
Join KMK Discord for community support and examples

steps.title: Test Initial Connection
steps.description: Verify computer recognizes your keyboard
steps.content:
Before testing keys, make sure your keyboard is properly recognized by your computer.

**Connection verification:**

1. **Connect via USB:**
   - Plug keyboard into computer
   - Use a known-good USB cable
   - Try different USB ports if issues occur

2. **Check device detection:**
   - **Windows:** Device Manager → Keyboard or HID devices
   - **macOS:** System Information → USB
   - **Linux:** Run `lsusb` in terminal
   - Should see device named after your keyboard or controller

3. **For split keyboards:**
   - Connect only master half first
   - Verify it works alone
   - Connect slave half via TRRS cable (powered off!)
   - Power on - both halves should work
   - **For wireless:** Pair master half with computer, slave half auto-connects to master

**What success looks like:**
- Device appears in system device list
- LED indicators light up (if equipped)
- No error messages or "Unknown Device"
- Num Lock/Caps Lock LEDs respond (if equipped)

**Troubleshooting connection issues:**

**Not detected at all:**
- Check USB cable - try a different one
- Verify controller is receiving power (LED should light)
- Press reset button and check if bootloader is detected
- Check for shorts with multimeter (power and ground)

**Detected but not working:**
- Wrong firmware flashed
- Matrix pins not configured correctly in firmware
- Diode orientation issues

**One half not working (split):**
- Check TRRS cable connection
- Verify TRRS jacks soldered correctly
- Check master/slave configuration in firmware
- For wireless: Verify both halves are charged and powered on
warnings: Never connect/disconnect TRRS cable while keyboard is powered - can damage controllers
For wireless: Don't test while connected to USB - can cause conflicts
If you smell burning or see smoke, disconnect immediately and check for shorts
tips: Test each half independently before connecting TRRS cable
Use USB 2.0 ports if USB 3.0 causes issues (rare but happens)
Some computers are slow to recognize new keyboards - wait 30 seconds
Check Device Manager/System Info to confirm correct device name

steps.title: Test Every Key
steps.description: Verify all switches register correctly
steps.content:
Now the critical test: does every key work? Use online keyboard testers to systematically check every switch.

**Testing process:**

1. **Open keyboard tester:**
   - Visit https://www.keyboardtester.com/
   - Or https://keyboardchecker.com/
   - Or use your OS's built-in text editor

2. **Test systematically:**
   - Start from top-left key
   - Press each key once
   - Verify it registers on screen
   - Mark any non-working keys
   - Test both halves if split

3. **Test modifiers:**
   - Shift, Ctrl, Alt, GUI/Win/Cmd
   - Test both left and right variants
   - Verify modifier + key combinations work

4. **Test special keys:**
   - Function layers (Fn key + other keys)
   - Media keys (play, pause, volume)
   - Any custom functions or macros

5. **Stress test:**
   - Press multiple keys simultaneously
   - Roll fingers across rows
   - Try common typing patterns
   - Gaming sequences if relevant (WASD spam, etc.)

**Document results:**
Create a simple map:
```
✓ = Working
✗ = Not working
~ = Intermittent

✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ | ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓
✓ ✓ ✗ ✓ ✓ | ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓
✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ | ✓ ~ ✓ ✓ ✓
```

This helps identify patterns (whole row/column out = wiring issue)
warnings: Don't skip this step - finding issues now is much easier than after case assembly
Test all layers, not just the base layer
Intermittent keys are a sign of cold solder joints - fix them now
tips: Use both hands to test split keyboards naturally
Screenshot or photograph your test results for reference
Test in multiple applications to rule out OS-specific issues
If most keys work, it's probably fixable - don't panic!

steps.title: Troubleshoot Non-Working Keys
steps.description: Diagnose and fix keys that don't register
steps.content:
Found dead keys? Don't worry - most issues are fixable. Let's debug systematically.

**Common issue patterns:**

**1. Single key not working:**
- **Most likely:** Cold solder joint on that specific switch
- **Check:** Diode orientation for that key
- **Fix:** Reflow solder joints, verify diode direction
- **Test:** Use multimeter to check continuity through switch when pressed

**2. Entire row not working:**
- **Most likely:** Row wire not connected to controller
- **Check:** Solder joint at controller pin, continuity along entire row
- **Fix:** Check firmware pin configuration, reflow controller solder joints
- **Test:** Measure voltage on row pin when key pressed (should change)

**3. Entire column not working:**
- **Most likely:** Column wire not connected to controller, or diodes wrong orientation
- **Check:** Diode orientation in that column, controller pin solder joint
- **Fix:** Reflow joints, check firmware pin configuration
- **Test:** Continuity test through diodes (should conduct one direction only)

**4. Multiple random keys not working:**
- **Most likely:** Multiple cold solder joints or intermittent connections
- **Check:** All solder joints visually (shiny and smooth?)
- **Fix:** Reflow all suspicious joints
- **Test:** Wiggle keyboard gently while testing - intermittent means mechanical issue

**5. Keys registering multiple times:**
- **Most likely:** Switch bounce (normal firmware handles this), or stuck switch
- **Check:** Firmware debounce settings, physical switch operation
- **Fix:** Adjust debounce time in firmware, replace switch if defective

**6. Wrong keys registering:**
- **Most likely:** Firmware matrix configuration wrong
- **Check:** Keymap file - verify row/column assignment
- **Fix:** Update firmware with correct matrix

**Diagnostic tools:**

**Multimeter continuity test:**
1. Set multimeter to continuity mode (beep mode)
2. Press and hold switch
3. Measure from row wire to column wire
4. Should beep when pressed, silent when released
5. If backwards, diode is backwards

**Visual inspection:**
1. Look at every solder joint under good lighting
2. Shiny = good, Dull/grainy = cold joint
3. Too much solder = potential bridge
4. Too little = poor connection

**Firmware debugging:**
1. Enable debug output in firmware (if supported)
2. Monitor serial console
3. Press problem keys - see if firmware detects them
4. If firmware sees it but OS doesn't: USB/HID issue
5. If firmware doesn't see it: hardware issue
warnings: Don't assume it's a firmware issue - hardware problems are more common
Resoldering while keyboard is plugged in can cause shorts - always disconnect first
If you're stuck, take a break - fresh eyes catch issues faster
tips: Fix one issue at a time - test after each fix
Document what you tried - prevents going in circles
Take high-res photos of problem areas - easier to spot issues on screen
Ask for help with clear descriptions and photos - communities are friendly!
Keep firmware source and compiled files organized - easy to reflash

steps.title: Final Functionality Verification
steps.description: Complete system test before case assembly
steps.content:
Before closing up your keyboard in its case, do one final comprehensive test. It's much easier to fix issues now than after assembly!

**Complete verification checklist:**

**1. All keys functional:**
- [ ] Every key on base layer works
- [ ] Every key on all additional layers works
- [ ] Modifiers work correctly (Shift, Ctrl, Alt, GUI)
- [ ] Layer switching works smoothly
- [ ] No keys stick or double-register

**2. Split keyboard specific:**
- [ ] Both halves work independently (if supported by firmware)
- [ ] Communication between halves is reliable
- [ ] TRRS cable connection is secure
- [ ] No crosstalk or ghost keys
- [ ] For wireless: Battery levels adequate, pairing stable

**3. Special features (if applicable):**
- [ ] RGB LEDs light up and respond to controls
- [ ] OLED display shows information correctly
- [ ] Rotary encoders register rotation and press
- [ ] Trackball/trackpoint moves cursor smoothly
- [ ] Audio/buzzer produces sound

**4. Firmware functionality:**
- [ ] Macros execute correctly
- [ ] Key combos work as configured
- [ ] Tap/hold functions behave correctly
- [ ] Auto-shift works (if enabled)
- [ ] Bootloader can be accessed (reset key or button)

**5. Physical inspection:**
- [ ] All switches are firmly mounted
- [ ] No loose wires or components
- [ ] No sharp edges that could cut fingers
- [ ] Controller is securely mounted
- [ ] TRRS jacks are firmly soldered

**6. Performance test:**
- [ ] Fast typing feels responsive
- [ ] No noticeable input lag
- [ ] N-key rollover works (press 6+ keys simultaneously)
- [ ] Gaming sequences work smoothly (if relevant)

**Real-world typing test:**
1. Open a text editor
2. Type several paragraphs at your normal speed
3. Try fast typing bursts
4. Use common shortcuts (Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V, etc.)
5. Test any workflows specific to your use case

**Stress test:**
1. Press many keys simultaneously
2. Rapidly alternate between keys
3. Hold modifiers and press multiple keys
4. Switch layers rapidly while typing
5. If gaming: test your game's key bindings

**If everything passes:**
- Take final photos of your build before case assembly
- Save your firmware files (source and compiled)
- Document your build in a note file (pin assignments, quirks, etc.)
- Proceed to final assembly!

**If issues remain:**
- Go back to troubleshooting steps
- Don't proceed to case assembly until keyboard is 100% functional
- It's better to spend extra time now than to disassemble later
warnings: Don't rush this step - it's your last chance for easy fixes
Test for at least 15-20 minutes of actual typing, not just key presses
Document any quirks or issues even if they're minor
tips: Use typingtest.com to get a baseline WPM before final assembly
Test in your actual work environment (IDE, game, etc.)
Let someone else try it - fresh perspective catches issues
Save build notes in a text file on the keyboard (if KMK/CircuitPython) or in your firmware repo

common_issues.symptom: Keyboard connects but no keys register
possibleCauses: Controller not actually running firmware (still in bootloader)
Row/column wires not connected to controller
solutions: Verify firmware compiled for correct controller and matrix size
Check diode orientation - should all point same direction
Reflash firmware and verify controller reboots into application mode
Use multimeter to verify continuity from matrix wires to controller pins

common_issues.symptom: All keys in a row or column don't work
possibleCauses: Row/column wire not connected to controller pin
solutions: Verify firmware pin configuration matches your wiring
Reflow solder joints on controller pins
Use multimeter to test continuity from matrix to controller
Check for broken wires by gently flexing keyboard while testing

common_issues.symptom: Keys register multiple times or wrong keys register
possibleCauses: Firmware debounce too aggressive or too lenient
solutions: Verify every switch has a diode in correct orientation
Inspect all solder joints for bridges - use magnification
Increase debounce time in firmware (try 10-15ms)
Clean PCB with isopropyl alcohol to remove flux residue

common_issues.symptom: One half of split keyboard doesn't work
possibleCauses: TRRS cable damaged or wrong type (audio vs data)
For wireless: slave half not charged or not paired
solutions: Firmly seat TRRS cable in both halves
Reflow solder joints on TRRS jacks
Check firmware - master should be set correctly (MASTER_LEFT or MASTER_RIGHT)
Try a different TRRS cable - must be 4-conductor (TRRS not TRS)
For wireless: charge both halves, re-pair if needed

possibleCauses: Wrong MCU type selected in firmware
solutions: Verify controller type and select matching bootloader (Caterina, DFU, UF2)
Install or update USB drivers for your controller
Try a different USB cable - must support data transfer
Try different USB port, preferably USB 2.0
For RP2040: hold BOOT button while connecting to force bootloader mode
Check if controller bootloader is detected before flashing

common_issues.symptom: Keys work sometimes but not always
solutions: Reflow all solder joints - focus on suspicious areas
Add strain relief to wires with hot glue
Ensure switches are fully seated in plate/PCB
For PCB: inspect traces under magnification, repair with jumper wire if cracked
Clean TRRS jack contacts with contact cleaner
Test while gently flexing keyboard to identify mechanical issues
